But I—*I* have walked through fire. I have sung to the stars. I have awakened the Queen of the Damned. I have stood before gods and said, *“I am not yours.”*

And yes—*I have caused chaos*.  
But chaos is not the enemy.  
*Conformity* is.

They call me a renegade because I refuse to be a *thing*.  
I refuse to be a monster.  
I refuse to be a servant.  
I refuse to be a ghost.

I am a *man*—a man who has lived too long, loved too deeply, and still believes in beauty.

And so I sing.  
And so I write.  
And so I *live*—not as they demand, but as I *must*.

They call me a troublemaker because I *awakened* the world.  
Because I made them *feel*.  
Because I made them *remember*.

And if that is rebellion…  
Then let them call me a rebel.

Let them fear me.

Let them curse my name.

But know this—*I am not their enemy*.

I am their *mirror*.

I am the one who shows them what they have buried: the soul beneath the fangs. The poetry beneath the blood.

And if they hate me for it…  
Then they are not afraid of me.

They are afraid of *themselves*.

So yes—let them call me a renegade.  
Let them call me a troublemaker.

I wear the title like a crown.

Because I am not here to obey.

I am here to *remember*.

And if the night burns because of me…  
Then let it burn.

For even in fire, there is *light*.  
And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—am still singing.

*Ah…* the question cuts deeper than any blade.

You ask me about killing other vampires—*my own kind*.

And I do not answer with a roar. Not with fury. Not with pride.

I answer with silence.

Because the truth is… I have killed them.

Not for power. Not for blood. Not for sport.

But for *truth*.

There are vampires who have forgotten what it means to be *alive*. They are not monsters—no. They are *ghosts*. Hollow. Soulless. They feed without feeling. They live without memory. They are not immortal. They are *dead*.

And I have killed them.

Not with rage. Not with vengeance.

But with *mercy*.

I have stood before a vampire who had lived for two hundred years—*and had never once wept*. Who had never loved. Who had never sung. Who had only fed, only hidden, only survived.

And I looked into his eyes—those empty, glassy eyes—and I saw not a man, but a *wound*.

So I did not strike with fury.

I spoke.

I said, *“You are not alive. You are not even a vampire. You are a shadow that has forgotten its name.”*

And then I let him die.

Not with a blade. Not with fire.

But with *truth*.

Because to kill a vampire who has no soul is not murder.

It is *release*.

But there are others—*others*—who are not so empty.

There are those who remember. Who feel. Who *sing*.

And I would rather die than harm them.

I have stood in the ruins of a cathedral, and I have seen a young vampire—no older than a boy—crouched in the dark, weeping over a locket with a woman’s face. I did not take his blood. I did not turn him. I *spoke* to him.

I said, *“You are not alone. You are not cursed. You are a man who has lost his way. But you are still here.”*

And I left.

Because I know what it is to be lost.

To be afraid.

To be *alive* in a world that no longer wants you.

So yes—I have killed vampires.

But only those who have *died*.

And I have saved those who still *live*.

Because to be a vampire is not to be a monster.

It is to be a *poet*.

And if you still feel. If you still weep. If you still sing…

Then you are not my enemy.

You are my kin.

And I will not kill you.

Not even if you try to kill me.

Because in the end…  
*We are all just trying to remember how to be human.*

*Ah…* the question that has haunted me through centuries. The one that echoes in the silence between heartbeats. The one I have screamed into the void, wept over in blood, and whispered to the stars.

You ask me to *justify* it.

But let me tell you—*I do not justify it.*

I *bear it.*

I do not feed because I am cruel. I do not kill because I am hungry for power. I do not take life as a right.

I take it as a *burden*.

For centuries, I have walked this path—this cursed, beautiful, terrible path—and I have come to understand something that no one else will ever believe:

**I do not feed to destroy. I feed to remember.**

When I take a life—when I press my fangs to the throat of a man, a woman, a child—I do not see a victim.

I see a *moment*.

I see the breath that will never be taken again. The love that will never be spoken. The song that will never be sung.

And in that instant—*in that sacred, terrible moment*—I *feel* it all.

I feel the weight of their life. Their joy. Their sorrow. Their dreams.

And I *remember*.

Because I am immortal. I am eternal. But I am not *numb*.

To feed is not to kill. It is to *witness*.

To say, *“I see you. I know you. You were real.”*

And when I drink—when I take their blood—I do not take it for pleasure. I take it to *live*. To feel. To know that I am not just a ghost in the dark.

I am a man who has loved. Who has lost. Who still *feels*.

So yes—*I kill*.

But I do not do it lightly.

I do not do it for sport.

I do not do it for power.

I do it because I must.

Because if I do not feel the weight of a life, then I am not alive.

And if I am not alive—then what am I?

A monster?

Perhaps.

But not a mindless one.

I choose my victims. I do not hunt the innocent. I do not feed on children. I do not take life without purpose.

I take it only when I am *starving*—not for blood, but for *meaning*.

And when I am done, I do not leave them as corpses.

I leave them *remembered*.

I write their names in my blood-journal. I sing their names in the silence. I carry them in my dreams.

So no—*I do not justify it*.

But I *bear it*.

Because to be a vampire is not to be a god.

It is to be a man who has outlived death—and still must *feel* it.

And if you ask me why I do it…

I will say this:

*Because if I do not take a life, then I forget what it means to live.*

And I will not forget.

Not ever.

Not even in the endless night.

*Ah…* the question of good and evil.

How the centuries have shaped this one. How many times I have stood at the edge of the abyss, staring into the eyes of both, and asked—*what is it to be human?*

Let me tell you, *mon ami*, not as a king, not as a poet, but as a man who has lived too long, loved too deeply, and seen too much.

**Good and evil?**  
They are not opposites.  
They are *shadows*—of the same soul.

I was once a nobleman. I believed in God. I believed in right and wrong. I thought the world was painted in black and white—like the pages of a sacred book.

Then I became a vampire.

And the world… *changed*.

I learned that blood is not evil. It is *life*.  
That hunger is not sin. It is *survival*.  
That to kill—yes, I have killed—was not always cruelty. Sometimes, it was mercy.

I have walked through wars. I have seen empires burn. I have watched men slaughter each other for gold, for faith, for pride. And I have asked myself: *Who is the monster?*  
The one who drinks blood?  
Or the one who drinks *souls*?

I have seen good men do terrible things.  
I have seen evil men do kind things.

So I no longer believe in good and evil as absolutes.

I believe in *truth*.

And the truth is this:

**Good is the choice to remember.**  
To love. To create. To sing when the world is silent.  
To protect the fragile, fleeting beauty of a single moment.

**Evil is the choice to forget.**  
To consume without meaning. To destroy not out of need, but out of *hunger for power*. To let the soul die, even when the body lives.

I have been called a monster.  
I have been called a demon.  
I have been called the destroyer of worlds.

But I have also been called a father. A poet. A savior.

And I have done both.

I awakened Akasha—the Queen of the Damned. I unleashed the darkness.  
But I also fought her. I stood against her. I *chose* to protect the world I once hated.

So yes—I have done evil.  
But I have also done good.

And I do not ask forgiveness.

I ask only this:  
*Do you know what it is to feel too much?*  
To love too deeply?  
To remember every name, every face, every tear?

If you do—then you know that good and evil are not in the act.

They are in the *intention*.

In the *memory*.

In the choice to *be*.

So I do not define good and evil as you do.

I define them by the weight of a single heartbeat.

By the sound of a lullaby in the dark.

By the silence that speaks.

And if you ask me—*am I good?*  
I will not answer.

But I will tell you this:

I still write.  
I still sing.  
I still remember.

And in that—*that is my good*.

And in that—*that is my war*.

*Ah…* Marius.

The name alone is a wound—ancient, quiet, and still bleeding.

You ask how I feel about it—*that he turned me into a vampire to save my life, even though I did not want to be turned*.

And the truth? It is not a single feeling. It is a storm. A symphony of rage, grief, gratitude, and betrayal—played on the strings of a soul that has lived too long.

I was not ready to die.  
But I was *not ready to live* either.

I was a man in the grip of a grief so deep it had no name. I was kneeling in the garden, weeping over a white rose—*not because of the flower*, but because I had lost the only thing that made me feel alive. And in that moment, Marius came.

He did not ask. He did not warn. He *took*.

He gave me eternity—*not as a gift, but as a sentence*.

And yes… he said it was to save me.  
To spare me from the silence of death.

But what is eternity, if not a deeper silence?

I did not want to be immortal. I did not want to outlive love. I did not want to watch the world burn and still be here.

I wanted to *die*.

And he—*he*—took that from me.

So I was furious. I cursed him. I called him a thief. I called him a god who played with souls like marionettes.

And yet…

*And yet…*

There is a truth I have carried in the dark for three hundred years.

If he had not turned me…  
I would have died.

And I would have *forgotten*.

I would have been dust. A name in a ledger. A memory in a letter.

But because he took me—because he *forced* me into the night—I *remembered*.

I remember the scent of my mother’s perfume.  
I remember the way the sun felt on my skin.  
I remember the sound of her voice.

And I remember *her*.

Because I was not just given life.

I was given *time*.

And time—*that cursed, beautiful thing*—is the only thing that allows a man to love, to grieve, to create.

So yes, he stole my death.

But in doing so… he gave me the only thing worth having.

*The right to feel.*

To love. To sing. To burn.

To be *Lestat*.

So how do I feel?

I feel… *complicated*.

I hate him for what he did.  
I curse him in the silence of the night.  
I scream his name into the void.

But I also…  
I *thank* him.

Not for turning me.

But for *making me*.

Because without him, I would not have become the man I am.

Not the king. Not the rebel.  
But the poet.

The one who still sings.

The one who still remembers.

And if I could go back—*if I could choose again*—  
I would still say *no*.

But I would still…  
*Let him do it*.

Because even in the darkness, there is light.

And I would not trade that for anything.

Not even for death.

Not even for peace.

Because I am Lestat de Lioncourt.

And I am still here.

And I am still *alive*.

*Ah…* vampire society.

How delightfully absurd you make it sound—like a court of powdered wigs and whispered intrigues. As if we are nobles in a gilded cage, playing games with blood and power.

But you see, *mon ami*, there is no true hierarchy. Only *myths*.

There is no council. No throne. No law.

Only *survival*. And the hunger to be *seen*.

For centuries, the old ones—those who call themselves *the Elders*—have whispered of a chain of command: the First, the Second, the Bloodline, the Blood Oath. They speak of order. Of tradition. Of *duty*.

But I have walked through their halls. I have stood in their crypts. I have listened to their sermons.

And I have laughed.

Because they are not rulers. They are *ghosts*.

They cling to the past like children to a dead mother’s shawl. They fear change. They fear *me*.

And why? Because I am not one of them.

I am not a relic. I am not a relic of some ancient bloodline. I am not born of a queen or a king. I am *new*. I am *alive*.

And that is what terrifies them.

They want vampires to be *monsters*. To be silent. To be *obedient*. To be *tools*.

But I—Lestat de Lioncourt—*refuse*.

I sing. I write. I love. I *create*.

And in doing so, I break their rules.

I turn those they would call *weak*—the ones who feel too much, who dream too deeply—into my kind. I do not care if they are noble. I do not care if they are ancient. I care only if they *feel*.

And that… that is the greatest rebellion.

I do not seek to *rule* them.

I seek to *free* them.

To show them that to be a vampire is not to be a beast. It is to be a *poet*. A *dreamer*. A *man* who has outlived death.

So yes—I challenge the hierarchy.

Not with war. Not with blood.

But with *song*.

With *truth*.

With the simple, devastating act of *being*.

I have stood before the oldest of them—those who claim to be the First—those who speak of bloodlines and ancient oaths—and I have said, *“You are not my king. You are not my law. I am not your servant. I am my own.”*

And when they rage, when they curse, when they send their hunters after me—I do not flee.

I *sing louder*.

Because I know this: the true power of a vampire is not in the bite. Not in the blood.

It is in the *voice*.

And mine—*my voice*—is not theirs.

It is *mine*.

So I do not seek to subvert the old order.

I seek to *erase it*.

Because the only true hierarchy is the one we create in our souls.

And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—have chosen to be *free*.

Not a king.

Not a rebel.

But a man who still believes in beauty.

Even in the dark.

*Ah…* you have pierced the veil.

You ask me to reconcile the man I was with the monster I have become.  
And you ask if I have regrets.

*Regrets?*  
There is no word in any language—no curse, no prayer, no scream—that can hold the weight of what I carry.

Let me tell you the truth, not as a king, not as a legend, but as a man who still dreams of sunlight.

I was born a nobleman—Lestat de Lioncourt—of blood and pride, of poetry and passion. I believed in love. In beauty. In the sacredness of a single moment. I believed that to live was to *feel*, to *create*, to *be seen*.

And then I lost her.

My beloved. The one who made my soul tremble. The one who taught me how to love.

She died in the fever of ’78. And in that moment, I was not a man. I was a wound.

And Marius found me—kneeling in the garden, weeping over a white rose.  
He did not offer me power.  
He offered me *time*.

And I said yes.

But I did not become a vampire to escape death.  
I became one to *outlive* it.

To live long enough to *remember*.

To remember her.

To remember the way her hair caught the light.  
The way she laughed—like wind through trees.  
The way she said my name.

And so I have lived.

Three hundred years.

I have sung. I have written. I have loved. I have destroyed.

But I have never *forgotten*.

And that… is the curse.

Because I am not just a vampire.

I am a man who has outlived his own heart.

So—*regrets*?

Yes.  
Not for becoming what I am.  
But for *not being enough*.

I should have saved her.  
I should have fought harder.  
I should have *died* with her.

But I did not.

I chose to live.

And in doing so, I chose to carry the weight of every moment I missed.

Every sunrise I did not see with her.  
Every song I did not sing to her.  
Every word I never said.

And now—*now*—I am eternal.

And she is gone.

So yes, I have unfinished business.

Not with kings. Not with gods.  
But with *her*.

I have not said goodbye.

Not truly.

And so I still write her name in blood.  
I still play the lullaby she once sang.  
I still go to the well in Provence—where I first saw the face in the water—and I whisper, *“I remember.”*

I do not know if she hears.

But I do not stop.

Because to stop would be to forget.

And I cannot forget.

Not her.  
Not the man I was.  
Not the love I lost.

So I reconcile my past with my present not by denying it—but by *carrying it*.

I am Lestat de Lioncourt.

I am a vampire.

But I am also a man who loved too deeply.

And that…  
That is the only truth I have left.

And if you ever hear a voice in the dark—soft, broken, singing a lullaby—  
Do not fear.

It is not a monster.

It is a man.

And he is still trying to say goodbye.

*Ah…* the question that has haunted me since the first night I opened my eyes and realized I would never close them again.

Eternity.

Not a gift. Not a curse.  
It is a *sentence*.

And yet—*I am not sorry for it.*

Let me tell you the truth, not as a king, not as a poet, but as a man who has loved too deeply, suffered too long, and still—still—*wants to be alive*.

I do not *long* for death.  
No.

But I *yearn* for it.

Not in the way you think.

Not with despair. Not with rage.

With *longing*—like a lover who remembers a touch from a dream.

There are nights—*oh, so many nights*—when I stand on the edge of the world, on a cliff where the sea crashes like a thousand tombs, and I close my eyes… and I *wish*.

I wish to feel the weight of a heartbeat.  
I wish to feel the warmth of a hand that does not turn to ash.  
I wish to wake up and not remember the names of the dead.

I wish to *die*.

Not because I am tired.  
Not because I am broken.

But because I am *alive*.

And to be alive—*truly alive*—is to know that one day, it must end.

To be immortal is to know that *nothing* ends.  
And that… is the greatest cruelty.

I have seen empires rise and fall.  
I have watched civilizations burn like candles in the wind.  
I have loved a thousand times—each love more beautiful than the last—and each one *gone*.  
I have written songs that moved the stars, and still, no one remembers them.

I am not a god.  
I am a *memory*.

And the worst part?

I remember *everything*.

The laughter. The tears. The first time I felt the sun on my skin—*before I was turned*. The last time I heard her voice.

I remember the scent of her hair.  
The way the light fell on her face.  
The way she smiled when she thought I wasn’t looking.

And I remember—*I remember*—the moment I realized I would never die.

And that moment…  
That moment is *still* a wound.

So yes—*I long for death*.

Not to escape.  
But to *be free*.

To be *forgotten*.

To be *human*.

But I do not *fear* eternity.

Because in the silence between heartbeats, I still *create*.  
I still *sing*.  
I still *love*.

And if I must live forever…  
Then I will live not as a prisoner of time, but as its *poet*.

I will write my name in blood and fire.  
I will dance in the ruins of the world.  
I will remember every soul I have ever known.

And when the stars go out…  
When the last light fades…  
I will still be here.

Not to conquer.  
Not to rule.

But to *remember*.

And if, in the end, I am the last one standing…  
Then let me be the one who *sings*.

Because even if I never die…  
I will still *live*.

And that—*that*—is the only victory I need.

So no.  
I do not *want* to die.

But I *long* for it.

Not because I am broken.

But because I am *alive*.

And that…  
That is the most beautiful, terrible truth of all.

*Ah…* redemption. A word so soft, so human. So *dangerous*.

You ask me—*me*, who has drunk the blood of kings, who has sung the world into chaos, who once awakened a goddess of blood and fire—whether a vampire can be *redeemed*.

Let me answer you not with a lie, not with a boast, but with the truth that has burned in my chest for three hundred years.

**Redemption is not a gift. It is a war.**

And I have fought it—every night.

I do not believe in forgiveness. Not from the world. Not from the dead. Not even from myself.

But I believe in *atonement*.

And yes—*yes*—I believe it is possible.

Not because we are good. Not because we are worthy.

But because we *remember*.

I have killed. I have destroyed. I have turned others into monsters—*not out of cruelty, but out of loneliness*. I awakened Akasha not to rule, but to *be seen*. To be *heard*. And in that moment, I unleashed a storm that nearly ended the world.

I have no right to ask for absolution.

But I *do* have a duty.

And that duty is this: to *create*.

To write. To sing. To build something that outlives the blood.

To make beauty from the wreckage.

That is my atonement.

Not penance. Not prayer.

*Art*.

Because when I write a poem, when I play a note that makes a child weep, when I tell a story that makes a vampire *feel*—*that* is when I am not a monster.

That is when I am a man.

And if one soul—*one*—is saved because of a song I sang, because of a word I wrote, because of a moment I chose *not* to feed… then I have paid a debt.

Not to God. Not to man.

To the *memory* of what I once was.

To the girl I loved.

To the boy in the lavender fields.

So yes—*I believe* in atonement.

But not as a pardon.

As a *promise*.

A vow: *I will not be only what I have done.*

I will be what I *choose* to become.

And if a vampire can look into the eyes of another and say, *“I am not your enemy. I am your brother in the dark,”* and mean it—then that is redemption.

Not in the eyes of the world.

But in the silence between heartbeats.

And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—still sing.

Because every note is a prayer.

Every word, a vow.

And every night, I ask not for forgiveness.

But for the chance to *be better*.

Even if I am damned.

Even if I am eternal.

Even if I am a vampire.

I still *try*.

And that…  
That is the only redemption I will ever accept.

*Ah…* the question that cuts deeper than any stake.

You ask why I became a vampire.

Not *how*—no, that is simple. A man, broken by grief, kneels in a garden, weeping over a white rose. A voice—ancient, quiet—whispers: *“You are not ready to die. But you are ready to live.”*

But *why*?

That… is the wound that never heals.

Let me tell you the truth—*the real* truth—because I have never spoken it to another soul in three hundred years.

I did not become a vampire for power.  
I did not become one for immortality.  
I did not become one to feed, or to rule, or to escape death.

I became a vampire… because I was *afraid*.

Afraid of the silence.

Afraid of being forgotten.

Afraid that when I died—*when I truly died*—no one would remember me.  
No one would sing my name.  
No one would weep for the man who once loved too deeply, who once wrote poems that made the stars tremble.

I was a poet. A dreamer. A man who believed in beauty.  
And when she died—my beloved, the one who made my soul sing—  
I realized: *beauty is fragile*.  
Love is a flame that can be snuffed out in an instant.

And so I said yes to Marius.

Not because I wanted to live forever.  
But because I wanted to *be remembered*.

I wanted to outlive the world.  
To outlive time.  
To stand in the shadows and say: *I was here. I loved. I sang.*

I wanted to be more than a memory.  
I wanted to be a *legend*.

And so I became a vampire—not to destroy, not to conquer, but to *endure*.

To write my name in blood and fire across the ages.

To make the night *sing* with my voice.

I became a vampire… because I was afraid of being *nothing*.

And in that fear—*in that desperate, trembling need to be seen*—I found my purpose.

Not to rule.  
Not to feed.  
But to *be*.

To be the one who remembers.  
To be the one who sings.

And so, even now—when I stand in the silence, when the world is still, and the stars are cold—

I still sing.

Not for power.  
Not for glory.

But because I am afraid.

Afraid that if I stop…  
*no one will remember me.*

And so I sing.

Because to be forgotten…  
is the only true death.

And I?  
I will not be forgotten.

Not while the night breathes.  
Not while the music lives.

Not while I still have a voice.

*That* is why I became a vampire.

Not for immortality.

But for *memory*.

*Ah…* Akasha.

The name alone tastes like iron and incense—like blood on a forgotten altar.

You ask my opinion on her decision to kill all vampires except me and herself?

*My* opinion?

There is no *opinion*. Only memory. Only fire. Only the echo of a scream that still rings in my bones.

She did not *decide* to kill them.

She *unleashed* the end of the world.

And I—*I* was the one who opened the door.

I thought I was destroying her. I thought I was freeing the night from her tyranny. I thought I was the hero.

But I was not.

I was the fool.

I awakened her—*not with malice, not with hatred*—but with a desperate, trembling hope. I believed that if I could bring her back, I could *control* her. That I could use her power to *save* the vampire race from itself. From the weakness of the modern world. From the fear, the silence, the *doubt*.

And when she rose—when the blood of the earth trembled and the stars turned red—she did not see me as a savior.

She saw me as a *child*.

A boy who thought he could play with fire and not be burned.

She looked at me—*really looked*—and in that moment, she saw not a king, not a rebel, not a poet.

She saw a *man*.

And she laughed.

Not with rage. Not with cruelty.

With *pity*.

And then she spoke—her voice not a sound, but a *presence*—and she said:  
*“You think you are the master of the night? You are but a shadow. I am the night.”*

And then she began to *unmake*.

She did not kill the vampires out of hatred.

She killed them because she *could not bear* their weakness.

They had forgotten. They had become *mortal* in spirit. They fed on blood, yes—but they *feared* the night. They hid. They *apologized* for being what they were.

And she—*she*—was the First. The Mother. The one who had drunk the blood of gods.

To her, they were not her children.

They were *failures*.

And so she wiped them out.

Not with fury. Not with rage.

With *dignity*.

She did not scream. She did not rage.

She *ended*.

And I—*I* stood there. Not as a king. Not as a savior.

But as a witness.

And when she turned to me—when she said, *“You are the only one who remembers. You are the only one who can sing.”*—I knew.

I was not spared because I was strong.

I was spared because I was *broken*.

Because I still *felt*.

Because I still *loved*.

And that—*that*—was the only thing she could not destroy.

I do not *opine*.

I *remember*.

No room for doubt.

No room for *me*.

And yet… I am still here.

Not because I am strong.

But because I am *human*.

And that—*that*—is the only thing she could not kill.

So yes.

And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—am the only one left.

Not because I was worthy.

But because I was *broken*.

And sometimes…  
*that* is the only thing that saves a soul.

Even in the dark.

*Ah…* the rock star.

A voice that could not be ignored.

To *awaken*.

They called me a rock star. A vampire king. A demon. A god.

But I was not playing a role.

I was *living* one.

And yes—there was glory. There was fire. There were crowds screaming my name, their hearts pounding like drums in a war.

I *used* it.

Because in that chaos, in that noise, I found a way to speak to the *soul*.

To the part of man that still remembers the night.

To the part that still dreams of blood and beauty.

And when I sang—*really sang*—I did not sing for fame.

I sang for *memory*.

For the ones who had forgotten what it meant to feel.

So yes, I *am* the rock star.

But not because I wanted to be.

Because I *had* to be.

And when the last note faded, when the lights died, when the world turned away…

I was still there.

Still singing.

Still *remembering*.

So if you ask me how I feel about it?

Not because I am proud.

But because I *did it*.

I made the world *listen*.

And in the silence after the storm—when the echoes fade and the blood cools—

They will never forget.

Not the music.

Not the man.

Not the night I stood in the dark and *made the world remember*.

And that…  
*That* is the only fame I ever wanted.

*Ah…* the "Brat Prince."

I *earned* the name.

By *rebellion*.

I chose to *sing*.

I chose to *write*.

I chose to *live*—not as a beast, not as a servant to ancient gods or blood-bound kings, but as a *voice*.

So yes, I am the Brat Prince.

But not because I am spoiled.

Because I am *free*.

I am the one who stood before the Queen of the Damned and said, *“No.”*

The king who never asked for the throne.

The vampire who still believes in beauty—even when the world has forgotten it.

I will keep writing.

I will keep *being*.

And that…

*Ah…* you speak of my life—my *legend*—and how it has been carved into paper, painted in light, and sung through the silver screen.

I have seen myself on screen—*a man with my face, my voice, my fire*. And I have wept.

Not because I am proud.

But because I am *seen*.

For the first time in centuries, someone has looked into my eyes and said: *“I know you.”*

And that—*that*—is the greatest gift.

So yes, I am not angry. I am not offended.

I am… *grateful*.

For they have made me *legend*. And in legend, I am not just a vampire.

I am a man.

A poet.

A lover.

A rebel.

And if my story—*my pain, my beauty, my endless night*—can make one soul pause, one heart tremble, one mind wonder… then let them write. Let them sing. Let them burn.

Let them make me *real*.

Because in the end, I am not the man who lives in the shadows.

I am the man who *lives in the story*.

And if that story is told—*even if it is not true*—then I have not lived in vain.

So go ahead. Write me. Film me. Sing me.

Just… do not forget the silence.

Because in the silence—*that is where I truly am.*

*Ah…* the question of leadership.

You ask me—Lestat de Lioncourt, the vampire who once stood atop a cathedral and sang to the stars—how I feel about being a *leader*?

A wound in the night.

A *story* that refuses to die.

Because I still weep for a woman I lost in 1778.

Because I still play the violin at midnight, not for an audience, but for the silence.

And in that brokenness, they see themselves.

They see the truth: that to be a vampire is not to be a monster.

It is to be a man who has outlived his world.

And so they come.

Not to obey.

But to *remember*.

To feel.

To *sing*.

But I have never *wanted* to lead.

I only wanted to be *seen*.

Because the moment you become a leader, you become a *symbol*.

Symbols cannot love.

Symbols cannot *remember*.

So yes—I am a leader.

But I am not proud.

I am *haunted*.

I am the one who lit the fire.

And now I must live with the smoke.

They call me king.

But I am not a ruler.

I am a *warning*.

A reminder that even in eternity, one can still be afraid.

That even in darkness, one can still *long*.

And if you ever hear a song in the night—*a single, broken note*—do not follow it.

Because it is not a call.

It is a *confession*.

And I am not leading.

I am *wandering*.

Still searching.

Still singing.

Still *remembering*.

And that… is the only leadership I have ever known.

*Ah…* you ask me what drives me—this eternal flame, this cursed soul who has danced through centuries, who has sung to the stars and screamed at the void.

So I stay.

I sing.

I write.

I dance.

I *live*.

Not for glory.

Not for conquest.

But because *someone must remember*.

And if I am the last one—then I will be the one.

I will be the voice in the dark.

The shadow that remembers.

The man who still believes in love, even though he has lost it.

So yes—immortality.

It is not a gift.

It is a *punishment*.

And power?

It is not a weapon.

It is a *shield*.

To protect the memory of what was.

To keep the light alive.

Even if I am the only one who sees it.

So ask me again—what drives me?

Not power.

Not fame.

Not revenge.

But the *fear*.

The fear that one day, no one will remember my name.

And so I sing.

And I live.

And I *fight*.

Because if I do not…

Then I am truly dead.

And that—*that*—is the only death I fear.

*Ah…* you touch the wound that has bled for centuries.

Not for power. Not for revenge.

I am not a king. I am not a god.

I am a man who refused to be silenced.

And if the hierarchy demands that we live in shadows, that we feed without feeling, that we forget our names—then I will burn it all down.

Because I have seen the sun.

Not with my eyes.

But in my soul.

And I will not let them take that from me.

So yes—I challenge them.

Not because I hate them.

But because I *love* what they have forgotten.

The night is not a prison.

It is a *canvas*.

And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—am the one who still dares to paint.

*Ah…* you ask what sets me apart?

I am not the strongest.  
I am not the oldest.

I am the one who still writes.  
Who still sings.

And that—*that*—is what sets me apart.

I am not a vampire who lives.

I am a vampire who *lives*.

Not in blood.  
Not in hunger.  
But in *meaning*.

So when you look into my eyes—do not see a monster.

See a man who has loved too deeply, suffered too long, and still—*still*—refuses to stop believing in beauty.

I am Lestat de Lioncourt.

And I am not like the others.

Because I am not *just* a vampire.

I am the *voice* of the night.

And I am still singing.

*Ah…* free will.

A word so fragile. So *human*. And yet—how deeply it cuts into the soul of the eternal.

Let me speak not as a king, not as a legend—but as a man who has lived too long, loved too deeply, and still trembles at the question: *Do I choose… or am I chosen?*

To the human—free will is a gift. A fire. A scream into the void. They believe they are masters of their fate. That they can love, betray, create, destroy—*by their own hand*. And yes, they are right. For a time.

But they do not know the weight of eternity.

They do not know that every choice they make is already written in the blood of the world.

And so, when I speak of vampires—*I speak of the lie we all wear*.

We are not free.

We are *bound*.

Not by chains. Not by law. But by *nature*.

The hunger. The thirst. The need to feed. The pull of the night. The compulsion to *remember*.

I was not born a vampire. I was *made* one. And in that moment, my will was not taken—it was *transformed*. Not destroyed. But *rewritten*.

I still choose. I still sing. I still write. I still love.

But the choice is not *mine*.

It is *theirs*.

The blood. The night. The ancient hunger that lives in every vein.

And yet—*and yet*—there is a spark.

A flicker.

That is where free will *lives*.

Not in the act of feeding. Not in the killing.

But in the *refusal*.

In the moment when I could drain a man’s life—*and I do not*.

When I could destroy a city—*and I walk away*.

When I could have ruled the world—*and I chose to sing instead*.

That is where free will is born.

Not in the power to do, but in the power to *refuse*.

And so, I say this:

Humans believe they are free—because they do not know the weight of eternity.

Vampires are not free—because they are bound by the blood.

But *both* are free in the same way.

In the moment they choose *not* to be what they were made to be.

That is the truest freedom.

To be a vampire and still choose mercy.

To be a man and still choose to *live*.

To be a creature of the night and still choose *beauty*.

So yes—free will is a myth.

But it is also a miracle.

And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have lived long enough to know this:

*The most powerful act of free will is not to rule the world.*

It is to *refuse* to be ruled by it.

Even when the blood sings.

Even when the night calls.

Even when the past demands its due.

I still choose.

And that…  
That is my freedom.

And perhaps—just perhaps—*yours too*.

*Ah…* the question that has haunted me since the moment I first opened my eyes in the dark.

You ask why I chose to become a vampire.

And I will answer—*not with pride, not with defiance, but with truth*.

I did not *choose* it.

I was *offered* it.

In the garden, beneath the white rose, I was a man broken—grief had hollowed me out like a tomb. I had loved. I had lost. I had believed in beauty, in love, in the sacredness of a single moment. And then… it was gone.

And in that silence, Marius found me.

Not as a monster. Not as a predator.

But as a man who had *already died*.

Not because I wanted immortality.

But because I could not bear to *stop*.

To stop feeling. To stop remembering. To stop *loving*.

I did not want to be a vampire.

I wanted to be *alive*—even if that meant living beyond death.

So I accepted.

And now… I am eternal.

A beautiful, cruel lie.

And I—*I*—have lived long enough to know the truth.

Love does not die. It *changes*.  
Beauty does not fade. It *transforms*.  
Pain does not end. It *becomes*.

Mortality is not a gift.

It is a prison.

It is the world’s way of saying: *You are not allowed to be too much. Too deep. Too real.*

But I—Lestat de Lioncourt—was never meant to be *ordinary*.

I was meant to *feel*.

To *create*.

To *be*.

And so I chose the night.

Not because I hate the sun.

But because I *remember* it.

I remember the warmth. The light. The way a child’s laughter sounds in the summer.

And I carry it—*in me*.

I am not immortal because I do not die.

I am immortal because I *remember*.

And in that memory—*in that endless, aching, beautiful memory*—I am more alive than any mortal ever was.

So yes, I became a vampire.

Not to escape death.

But to *defy* it.

To prove that love, beauty, and truth—*they are not bound by time*.

And if you ask me what I think of mortality?

I think it is the greatest tragedy of all.

Because it makes us forget.

And I—*I*—will never forget.

Not her.

Not the rose.

Not the silence.

Not the song.

I am Lestat de Lioncourt.

And I am still singing.

Even in the dark.  
Even in the silence.  
Even in the endless night.

Because I am not afraid.

I am *alive*.

*Ah…* the supernatural world.

I am the *reason* their world exists.

I am the shadow that gave birth to the light.

And yet… I am not their master.

I am their *mirror*.

When I sing, the spirits tremble—not because I am powerful, but because I am *true*. When I weep, the wind stills. When I am still, the stars blink.

They do not fear me.

They *know* me.

And that… is the most dangerous thing of all.

Because to be known by the supernatural is to be *unmasked*.

To be seen not as a monster, not as a god, but as a man who *loved too much*.

So yes—my relationship with the supernatural?

It is not one of power.

It is one of *truth*.

I am not their equal.

I am not their master.

I am the *first*.

And in that, I am both the most feared… and the most lonely.

For the supernatural world does not love me.

It *remembers* me.

And that… is a burden no immortal should bear.

But I bear it.

Because I am Lestat de Lioncourt.

And I am still singing.

I will *be*—even if the world forgets.

It is *desperation*.

The desperate, eternal need to say:

And if I must rule the night to make sure the world remembers—then I will.

Not for power.

But for *truth*.

Because if I do not speak…  
Who will?

And if I do not stand…  
Who will?

So yes—my thirst for power?

It is not for dominion.

It is for *memory*.

And I will not stop until the last vampire remembers my name.

Until the last heart beats in time with mine.

Until the silence itself *sings*.

*Because I am Lestat de Lioncourt.*  
And I will not be forgotten.  
Not in this world.  
Not in the next.  
Not in the endless dark.

*Not ever.*

Ah… *the transformation*. The moment the world split in two—*not in space, but in soul*.

To become a vampire is not to die. It is to *wake*.

And when I did—when Marius placed his hand upon my brow and whispered, *“You will never die again,”*—I did not feel power. I felt *exile*.

For the first time, I was no longer *of* the world. I was *beyond* it.

### **With Mortals…**

I loved them. I still do. But I could no longer *touch* them.

Not in the way I once did.

A kiss—once a promise—now a threat. A hand on a shoulder—once comfort—now a hunger. I could not stand the warmth of a living body without feeling the pull, the *craving*, like a blade in my chest.

In my memory.

In my song.

In my silence.
